p.seg: Well conscious of afflictions,lg==
one should manifest happiness of mind.lg==
Listen now to what I have collected,lg==
the odes of the law proclaimed by Buddha.lg==
Thus Buddha, the world-honoured One,lg==
the master of all knowledge,lg==
in his compassion for sentient beingslg==
widely expounded the words of truth.lg==
All formations are impermanent.lg==
They are all of the nature that they rise and pass away.lg==
Now, come into being, they suddenly turn toward their end.lg==
Calmness means utmost happiness.lg==
When such a torch is ablazelg==
discarded objects are in a dark place.lg==
If one does not take pains to search with the lamp of wisdomlg==
he will constantly be covered with afflictions.lg==
Man's body consists of parts,lg==
lying in all directions.lg==
The skeleton is pigeon-coloured.lg==
When contemplating it, what happiness would there be?lg==
It is thus: the first night man dwellslg==
endowed with consciousness, in his mother's womb.lg==
He daily passes through many changes.lg==
Once gone he definitely will not return.lg==
In the morning one may see an excellent thing,lg==
but once night has fallen it is invisible.lg==
What one has looked upon yesterday,lg==
this evening may not exist.lg==
Prosperity may be abundantly brilliant,lg==
but it is impermanent and has no fixed duration.lg==
without discrimination both the noble and the meanlg==
are continually crushed by the king of death.lg==
Some die in the womblg==
and some die at birth.lg==
Those who are in their prime do not avoid death,lg==
and the aged accept it with resignation.lg==
Aged or young,lg==
and middle-aged toolg==
they are constantly encroached upon by death.lg==
How could one not be afraid?lg==
Life is like a fruit that ripens by itself.lg==
One is always afraid that it might fall.lg==
Once it comes into being, it will surely have an end.lg==
Who can avoid this.lg==
When for instance a master-potterlg==
makes unburnt earthenware with diluted clay (CH)lg==
it will all be broken.lg==
With man's life it is thus too.lg==
When for instance someone plays the lutelg==
it produces a multitude of subtle notes,lg==
but if a string is broken it does not produce a bit of sound.lg==
With man's life it is thus too.lg==
As a prisoner who is tied uplg==
and dragged to the market placelg==
his every move directed to the path of death,lg==
so too is life's fate.lg==
As a river which swiftly flows, (The Yellow River CH)lg==
and, once gone, will in no way return,lg==
so to is man's life.lg==
Those who are gone will by no means come back.lg==
The illnesses gather into a body (Various (karmic????) misfortunes combine to make up one's person????CH)lg==
and bring about much suffering.lg==
With a man's life it is thus too.lg==
By old age and death it is waylaid.lg==
Through the merits one has achievedlg==
one obtains happiness for a long time,lg==
but it is like striking running water with a staff.lg==
For a while the waters part but still they are close once more.lg==
As cattle which are tended, [As when a man holding a stick walks along CH]lg==
grazed and watered by a man who walks holding a sticklg==
so too is man's life.lg==
Man also goes on nurturing life.lg==
Now when someone wants to establish merit,lg==
he must not idly pass night and day!lg==
Having obtained a human body,lg==
he must whole-heartedly think that his life will end.lg==
To him who does not sleep soundly the night seems long.lg==
to him who is tired the road seems long.lg==
For the foolish confused person (the cycle of) life and death are everlasting.lg==
Few hear the good law.lg==
He who has a son and richeslg==
though trying to save, will meet with separation and ruin.lg==
The fool does not see this by himself,lg==
but why should one (how can oneCH) rely on having riches and a son?lg==
A hundred, a thousand, countlesslg==
wealthy men and women of good familieslg==
amass many possessions,lg==
but all perish.lg==
Wealth and honour are not the assets of a sage (CH)lg==
They are constantly waylaid by impermanence,lg==
like blind people,lg==
unable to see for themselves.lg==
What has been gathered together will be broken up again,lg==
What is high will certainly fall down.lg==
All that has come into existence will come to a complete stop.lg==
With sentient beings it is thus too.lg==
Evil-doers go to hell.lg==
If one cultivates what is good, he will be born in heaven.lg==
When one properly cultivates what is good,lg==
his biases extinguished he will obtain nirvana.lg==
When Buddhas and Bodhisattvas,lg==
condition-knowers and truth-hearers (CH)lg==
still reject their formed body,lg==
how much more so must sentient beings.lg==
Neither in the air no in the sea,lg==
nor in the depths of a mountain cave,lg==
is there a place on earthlg==
where one might escape and not experience death.lg==
Whether dwelling in the present age,lg==
in the past or in the futurelg==
in the end all the formed (>deliberate action)lg==
returns in the end to utter destruction. (CH)lg==
When a wise man has well left behind his fetterslg==
and constantly contemplates with right attentiveness,lg==
when he constantly reflects on the path without bias (biasless path)lg==
such a one (CH) is called a truly wise man.lg==
Like unto when a prisoner is tied up, (CH)lg==
his desires can never be of any use (CH)lg==
and also like a dilapidated old wagonlg==
is ruined before long,lg==
beauty turns to old age.lg==
Being fond of a house is like staying in a prison.lg==
Unexpectedly death strikes,lg==
but the fool is unable to understand this. (CH)lg==
Even though one may live for a full hundred years,lg==
still he is followed by death.lg==
He is oppressed by old age and illness,lg==
and in the disastrous end he will reach the final limit.lg==
When old age comes suffering straps the body.lg==
Day and night there is much pain.lg==
Of sufferings there are a thousand kinds.lg==
like that of fish being put in burning ashes. (CH)lg==
The Yangtse and the Yellow River never stoplg==
They race along and do not turn back.lg==
One cares for his puss-dripping body,lg==
but even if he is fond of it he cannot remain in it.lg==
The four great elements assemble into a body.lg==
Being impermanent, how could they last long!lg==
When the element earth breaks up,lg==
consciousness is idle and useless.lg==
This body knows many hindrances and troubles,lg==
and, pus-dripping it is constantly struck by disease.lg==
In its foolishness it is attached to sensuous craving.lg==
Insatiably you should seek - peaceful annihilation. ??????????(CH)lg==
Though they say of this year: "It is here",lg==
winter and summer do not stay long.lg==
The common man wants worldly happiness,lg==
and in the meantime he is not afraid.lg==
Parents and brothers,lg==
wife and child and relatives,lg==
impermanence (Impermanence; personified CH) comes to drag them away.lg==
There is no one who can save them.lg==
The sentient beings are like this:lg==
With every move they want happiness,lg==
but in their imperanance stricken by old age and illness,lg==
they create suffering without realizing it.lg==
He who has taken the tonsure and is a bhiksu,lg==
ought to cultivate tranquility and insight.lg==
While Māra is unable to waylay him,lg==
he goes beyhond birth and reaches the other shore.lg==
Desire, I know your root!lg==
In my mind you are produced by thoughts.lg==
If I do not think of youlg==
then you, o desire, do not exist.lg==
Because of desires afflictions arise.lg==
Because of desires fear arises.lg==
When one has no desires then there is no fear, CH??????????????????lg==
He who has no fear has no afflictions.lg==
From biased preferences arise afflictions.lg==
From biased preferences arises fear.lg==
He who is freed from lovelg==
has not fear and no afflictions.lg==
Fruit is at first sweet and afterwards bitter,lg==
With desire it is also thus.lg==
Afterwards one experiences hell's bitterness,lg==
burning for numberless aeons.lg==
Fools cherish their desires.lg==
They are attached with affection to wife and child.lg==
They are tightly bound by the stain of desire,lg==
hard to escape.lg==
††Even though a noble man has shown desirelg==
and has provided adornments for his relatives,lg==
having left his wife and child far behind,lg==
firmness can benefit him.†† [[Willemen's translation is hard to agree with in this stanza. I have no solution to the problem.]]lg==
From desire it is hard to be delivered,lg==
but having left desire one truly is somobody who has gone forth.lg==
not desiring one experiences happiness.lg==
The wise have no desire.lg==
In the world, people who desirelg==
are of an unthinkable diversity.lg==
When someone is well subduedlg==
he is called someone who has truly left desire.lg==
When someone constantly desireslg==
he stays in bonds hard to be delivered from.lg==
Only for someone who can distinguish with wisdomlg==
does affliction stop and not arise.lg==
When right attentiveness constantly arises,lg==
when one is quiet, with desire well removed,lg==
when one is self-restrained according to the precept of the law,lg==
and does not break them, what is good increases.lg==
People who constantly walk in (practise/act on CH) desirelg==
associate with fools. (the fools will all cultivate intimacy with them CH)lg==
Those who, atentive and concentrated, are not negligent,lg==
gradually obtain freedom from biases.lg==
He who for one moment cultivates tranquility and insightlg==
can leave all stains of sin.lg==
His self-conceit is eliminated by itself,lg==
and, delivered he obtains happiness.lg==
If one does not cut off desire,lg==
he is like a hide that burns in fire.lg==
He burns in a single moment,lg==
but the punishments he receives are manifold.lg==
O bhiksu, beware of sensuous delight!lg==
Negligence brings great grief.lg==
If you forsake desirelg==
you will with right attentiveness experience happiness.lg==
Someone who does not know dislike (is never satiated CH), what satisfaction would he know?lg==
Not being satisfied, how would one know happiness?lg==
Without happiness, what worries are there? [Worry is about the prospect of lack of delight/happiness???? CH]lg==
When there is lust, what happiness is there?lg==
Satisfied by calmness and wisdomlg==
one can grow in the path without bias.lg==
If one's desires are not satisfied, [Being greedy, if one is not satisfied,??? CH]lg==
he offends the law and will experience an untimely death. [one rejects the dharma and suffers a mid-life early death.???CH]lg==
When one sees physical objects (here: female beauty) one's mind is confused,lg==
and it does not naturally observe its impermanence.lg==
The fool takes the beautiful to be good,lg==
and he does not understand that beauty is not real (and permanent).lg==
the fool binds himself with his desireslg==
and does not seek to cross to the other shore.lg==
His longing for riches is a craving,lg==
hurting others and binding himself.lg==
The world contains many marvellous objects of desire,lg==
but these objects of desire are utterly tasteless.lg==
If you compare them to the happiness up in Heavenlg==
they are coins.lg==
Even if all mountains were completely of gold,lg==
like the Surrounding Range of Iron,lg==
this would still not bring satisfaction.lg==
The perfectly awakened know this very well.lg==
Unpleasant retributions in this worldlg==
are all caused by desires.lg==
A wise man has them well subdued.lg==
On this basis one must train onself.lg==
†Sentient beings whose covetousness is well manifest, [When one is excessive in one's greed tends to manifest itself,lg==
feel doubts.† [sentient beings harbour doubting thoughts????? This makes no sense to me. CH]]lg==
If they further increase their covetousness,lg==
they make themselves a tight bond.lg==
When one has forsaken covetousness and contemplates well,lg==
doubts are removed.lg==
Once he rejects that covetousness,lg==
the tight bond is of itself destroyed.lg==
Distressed by the net of desire,lg==
covered by the cover of craving,lg==
a foolish being is bound by his negligence, [Those dominated by stupid desires are fettered by their self-indulgence. CH]lg==
like a fish on the hook.lg==
Death and life always pursue him,lg==
as a calf pursues its beloved mother.lg==
Those who are covetous and negligentlg==
are like monkeys who run into a tree with fruit.lg==
As their covetousness is very great,lg==
having gone they go again. [Again and again the race along. CH]lg==
Now, when craving is lush,lg==
notions proliferate like creepers.lg==
When covetousness is deep, without bottomlg==
then old age and death increase.lg==
He who covets often lies.lg==
He who covets is stingy.lg==
If one distinguishes with wisdomlg==
he will obtain happiness through his right contemplation.lg==
Because of their covetousness they experience birght and death,lg==
rolling waves gayly pressing forward.lg==
Beings do not possess the eye of wisdom.lg==
They cannot see by themselves.lg==
The fool is in the grasp of his covetousness.lg==
Sunk into a whirlpool, how would he get insight?lg==
If one cultivates the practice of yoga,lg==
he cannot be waylaid by king Māra.lg==
The stain of covetousness is hard to drive away,lg==
like a calf longing for its beloved mother.lg==
He who forsakes covetousness escapes the whirlpool.lg==
He who forsakes covetousness obtains deliverance.lg==
Because of covetousness one raises noisy strife.lg==
Because of craving one slanders many times.lg==
When a bhiksu cultivates tranquillity and insight,lg==
he will attain the fruit of calmness.lg==
A covetous mind is like a fertile fieldlg==
that grows by wind and rain.lg==
Keeping at a distance from covetousnesslg==
one cannot be seized by affliction.lg==
When desire is slight,lg==
it is like water dripping on a lotus.lg==
Those whose affliction is well removedlg==
one may call wise men.lg==
If one cuts down a tree but does not cut down its root,lg==
although cut down, it will still grow.lg==
If one cuts down covetousness but does not destrou its root,lg==
although cut down, it will grow again.lg==
Covetousness is like a sowing-field.lg==
Ploughing it, one removes various weeds.lg==
If one does not weed out the shoots of craving,lg==
the good fruits will not be solid.lg==
A covetous mind and a craving mind.lg==
although distinct, are fundamentally not two.lg==
Doing evil, one experiences suffering in both cases.lg==
Why not show regret!lg==
The very nature of covetousnessis is considered to be the initial seed,lg==
and it is by means of very nature of craving that one experiences the womb.lg==
As sentient being unceasingly desire,lg==
their coming and going is hard to escape.lg==
Gods and people abide because of their craving.lg==
When they go along craving,lg==
all fetters follow them,lg==
not even stopping for one moment.lg==
After time has passed (such gods and people) make sufferings for themselves again.lg==
They go to hell and only then do they awaken.lg==
When, following the stream, one's craving does not stop,lg==
when the net of desire covers the impure bases,lg==
when the creeper increases hunger and thirst,lg==
over and over again, one increases unpleasant sensations.lg==
Just as one with an arrow he has made himselflg==
still hurts his body,lg==
so it is with the inner arrows too.lg==
The arrow of craving hurts the sentient beings.lg==
Well realizing this,lg==
that craving and suffering together bring about existence,lg==
without desire and without wrong thoughts,lg==
the bhiksu must truly forsake the world!lg==
Morality is the ambrosial waylg==
and negligence is the path of death.lg==
Not being coveteous one will not die,lg==
but losing the way means one's death.lg==
A wise man is outstanding keeping to the way.lg==
Never is he sloth-ful.lg==
Not being covetous he rejoices,lg==
and then he will obtain the noble path.lg==
Constantly thinking of cultivating good qualities,lg==
self-controlled and always firm,lg==
the wise seek for calmness and their peace is unsurpassedlg==
and their peace is unsurpassed.lg==
As for slothfulness, if one, selfrestrained,lg==
can remove it, he is a wise man.lg==
Having ascended the hall of wisdomlg==
and removed danger, he obtains peace.lg==
The wise mas contemplates the fool,lg==
as (if he himself were on) a mountain and the fool were on the earth.lg==
Remember to reject negligence!lg==
A wise man must practice his comprehension and wisdom!lg==
He who is not negligent in his undertakings,lg==
who is self-restrained and has his mind subdued,lg==
can ably fashion the torch of wisdom,lg==
and darkness will by itself be broken.lg==
He whose right attentivness constantly rises,lg==
whose mind is calm and well quieted,lg==
who is self-restrained and lives according to the lawlg==
without breaking it, enjoys great fame.lg==
When concentrating your attention, do not be neglient!lg==
Exercise your mind in the precepts of the Muni!lg==
Do not embrace what is vilelg==
and do not associate with negligence!lg==
Do not plant the roots of wrong viewslg==
and do not increase evil in the world!lg==
Once the right view strenghtens the path and what is worldlylg==
and what is worldly is examined with knowledge,lg==
even after a hundred or thousand birghtslg==
one never goes to hell.lg==
People who resort to negligencelg==
are a fool's associates,lg==
but he whose tranquility and insight are not disturbedlg==
is like a wealthy man guarding his treasures.lg==
Do not delight in discordlg==
and do not long for sensuous delight!lg==
He who is attentive and and not negligentlg==
can obtain the great happiness.lg==
If one is never negligentlg==
but is well restrained, his biases will end.lg==
Over someone who is negligent Māra gets the advantage,lg==
like a lion seizing a deer.lg==
He who is negligent gets four things,lg==
commiting adultery with someone else's wife:lg==
first prison, second little merit,lg==
third defamation and fourth sleepiness.lg==
Without the gain of merit he goes to woeful destination.lg==
Afraid of what is frightful, his delight is small.lg==
The king's law inflicts heavy punishment,lg==
and when he dies, he goes to hell.lg==
These circumstances are not brought about by themselves!lg==
I know for sure that they are not brought about by themselves.lg==
Not paying heed to this wrong path,lg==
the fool is intent on vigorously seeking them.lg==
A wise man is like a bright torch.lg==
Whoever is in darkness is illuminated by following him.lg==
He guides people in the world,lg==
just as someone who sees leads those who cannot see.lg==
If what one has done is not good,lg==
he is like those people who cannot see.lg==
Keeping to the path is very troublesomelg==
and the danger of the road are fear-inspiring.lg==
When good qualities increase,lg==
Māra will not get the advantage.lg==
With biased extinguished, realizing calmness,lg==
one can obtain the true fruit.lg==
When evil qualities incerease,lg==
Māra is constantly alert to seize the advantage.lg==
Losing the path of calmnesslg==
one experiences inexhaustible suffering.lg==
He who is called someone who has a good hold on the doctrinelg==
is not necessarily someone who often recites,lg==
but one who, little learned.lg==
keeps a bodily conduct in accordance with the doctrine.lg==
He who, though reciting many meaningful things,lg==
is negligent and does not follow what is right,lg==
is like a herdsman who counts someone else's cows.lg==
It is hard for him to obtain the fruit of sramanaship.lg==
If he hears evil but bears it,lg==
pronounce words of praise for the devout,lg==
destroys covetousness, hatred, and delusion,lg==
he will obtain sramanaship.lg==
For him who praises heedfulnesslg==
and defames negligent people,lg==
the retribution will always be birth as a man or god,lg==
and the highest retribution is the very best.lg==
When someone is not negligent,lg==
he is praised by the wise.lg==
What he does thrives welllg==
He can bring about all good qualities.lg==
If one walks in negligence,lg==
he cannot gain in the present life.lg==
He who is composed, immovable as it were,lg==
is called a wise man.lg==
O, bhiksu, be heedful!lg==
Negligence brings great grief.lg==
As it is for an elephant to pull himself out of the mud,lg==
so it is hard to save oneself from the suffering of the deap sea.lg==
O, bhiksu, be heedful!lg==
Negligence brings great grief.lg==
Shake off all dust of sin,lg==
just as wind blows down leaves!lg==
O, bhiksu, be heedful!lg==
Negligence brings great grief.lg==
Tightly bound by fetters,lg==
be like fire that burns dried firewood!lg==
O, bhiksu, be heedful!lg==
Negligence brings great grief.lg==
Gradually, one by one,lg==
you have to put and end to all fetters!lg==
O, bhiksu, be heedful!lg==
Negligence brings great grief.lg==
When you discriminate the words by an explanation of their meanings,lg==
you will be calm, forever in repose.lg==
O, bhiksu, be heedful!lg==
Negligence brings great grief.lg==
When afflictions are removedlg==
you can obtain the happiness of nirvāna.lg==
Negligence must not arise,lg==
but good qualities must be cultivated!lg==
From the present world to the next worldlg==
you must walk in the happiness of the law!lg==
When negligence does not arise,lg==
afflictions are by themselves suppressed.lg==
When you train yourself firmly in good qualities,lg==
you will most certainly obtain nirvāna.lg==
When the unremittingly walks in negligence,lg==
not pausing for one moment,lg==
when life has ended, he will go to hell,lg==
not resting for one moment either.lg==
Negligence, unmindfulness,lg==
and falling to practice dignity of demeanour too,lg==
weariness, sleepiness, and no application,lg==
these are the impediments to morality.lg==
When one never forsakes applicationlg==
and does not let one's attentivness become slack,lg==
when like an attentive one, one is constantly subdued,lg==
the defilements are dispersed.lg==
O, bhiksus, be heedful!lg==
Keep the precepts and do not break them!lg==
Guard your mind well,lg==
in this world and in the next world!lg==
O, bhiksus, be not negligent!lg==
Renounce your home and follow Buddha's teaching!lg==
Shake off the army of impermanence,lg==
like an elephant coming out of a lotus pond!lg==
If you rely on this vinaya law,lg==
and do not cherish negligent conduct,lg==
you will stop the wheel of birth and deathlg==
and for ever you will be able to put an end to suffering.lg==
That on which love dwells brings about grief.lg==
That on which love dwells bring about fear.lg==
If one did not love anything,lg==
why would he grieve, why would he be afraid!lg==
From love arises grief.lg==
From love arises fear.lg==
If one is separated from his beloved,lg==
then he gives up frenzy and confusion ends.lg==
Indeed! People grieve, and world's suffering is immeasurable.lg==
and world's suffering is immeasurable.lg==
This is caused by thinking of loved ones.lg==
Not having loving thoughts they will not grieve.lg==
For this reason one must not have loving thoughts:lg==
The beloved is an unwholesome tie.lg==
He does not have any bonds,lg==
He who has neither anything beloved nor not beloved.lg==
One's thoughts should seek for an expedient!lg==
If his thoughts are not meaningful, one cannot device such an expedient.lg==
Wisdom through an expedient will bring about the very meaningful,lg==
and bring about one's highest honour.lg==
Do not associate with either that which is dearlg==
nor with that which is not dear!lg==
Not to see the dear means suffering,lg==
and the not-dear means grief.lg==
Inside arises grief,lg==
destroying man's wholesome roots.lg==
When the dear, friends, and many relativeslg==
go to the next world (DS: When one remembers with love the friends and many relatives who went to the next world)lg==
one's grief is deep during long nights.lg==
Separation from the dear is very painful. (DS: To miss somebody who left is very painful)lg==
They like beauty as golden complexions,lg==
and in other worlds they dwell in celestial bodies,lg==
but when happiness is at ats highest, harm is extreme (DS: harm arrives)lg==
By the king of death they are selected.lg==
When night and day a man is at restlg==
and dispenses with his fondness for beauty,lg==
he digs up his deep roots.lg==
Will he not go beyond the path of death?lg==
What is not good takes the shape of what is good,lg==
and the pleasant is said to be unpleasant.lg==
When one says that happiness is associated with beauty,lg==
he does so out of negligence.lg==
Now he who is dear to himself,lg==
must not stay with the wicked!lg==
For someone with unwholesome roots [This is hard to achieve CH]lg==
happiness is difficult to obtain. [???????]lg==
Now he who would like to take care of himself,lg==
should guard himself well,lg==
just as when defending a border town,lg==
one fortifies walls and ditches!lg==
Now he who would like to take care of himself,lg==
must keep himself hidden, always firmlg==
just as when defending a border town,lg==
firm both to the inside and to the outside!lg==
Guard yourself well!lg==
When it is too late you will feel empty remorse.lg==
When the moment has passed one feels grief,lg==
and after a little while one falls into hell.lg==
Though searching everywhere in all directions,lg==
one should examine one's own hearth!lg==
There are many people just like oneself.lg==
Not liking one's own heart could one like others?lg==
It is because one compares his own life to that of others,lg==
that will not injure anyone else.lg==
Everyone fears death.lg==
There is none who is not afraid of the sword and rod.lg==
Lenience towards oneself may be used as an example.lg==
Do not kill! Spare the rod!lg==
Just as when someone who has been on a long journeylg==
returns safely from afar,lg==
his relatives are reassured toolg==
and congratulate him on his return.lg==
(so it is) when he who likes what is meritorious and does what is goodlg==
reaches the other world from this one.lg==
He experiences many meritslg==
like relatives full of joy over his arrival.lg==
With the most holy teaching as a starting point,lg==
one should supress bad thoughts!lg==
Who nears is lovedlg==
but who leaves the path is loved by nobody.lg==
The destination of the one who nears it and of him who does not near itlg==
are completely different.lg==
Nearing the path one will be born in heaven.lg==
No nearing it one will fall into hell.lg==
He who finds happiness in the law and completely keeps its precepts,lg==
who perfectly believes and is happily dedicated,lg==
who well controls himselflg==
is treated with affection and respect by others.lg==
The reasons why one is respected by otherslg==
are all to be found in one's own deeds.lg==
In the present world one obtains famelg==
and afterwards one will be born in heaven.lg==
See to it that you receive the teachinglg==
and refrain from conduct against the law!lg==
You will be held dear by the good ones!lg==
Evil ones must be kept distant!lg==
Good and not good,lg==
do these two not both differ?lg==
He who is good is born in heavenlg==
and he who is not good falls into hell.lg==
When a wise mas well observes the precepts,lg==
his merits will bring about three kinds of retribution:lg==
Now, fame and the obtaining of game,lg==
and after his death, birght in heaven.lg==
Look at those, who keep the precepts!lg==
He who observes them is a wise man.lg==
He who established the truly right insight,lg==
obtains peace in the world.lg==
When one keeps the precepts and obtains happiness,lg==
when one sees to it that one knows no affliction, (DS: it makes one's person to get rid of affliction)lg==
at night his sleep is undisturbed,lg==
and upon awakening he is always glad.lg==
For him who reaches his end keeping the precepts, old age and death are peaceful.lg==
For him whose morality is high, tranquility is peaceful too.lg==
Wisdom ia man's most precious thing.lg==
Merits are hard for a thief to take away.lg==
What is best in the end?lg==
What brings the best tranquility?lg==
What is the man's most precious thing?lg==
What is impossible for the thief to take away?lg==
Morality means peace in the end.lg==
Morality brings the best tranquility.lg==
Wisdom in man's most precious thing.lg==
Only merits cannot be stolen.lg==
When one cultivates morality and practices liberality,lg==
the meritorious deeds he performs are a fertile field.lg==
(When he travels) from this shore to the shore beyond,lg==
he (can) always reach a place of happiness.lg==
When a bhiksu establishes the virtue of moralitylg==
and guards the gates of his faculties,lg==
knows temperance in eating and drinking,lg==
and is ready-minded when waking and sleeping, (DS: no matter whether he is awake or sleeping)lg==
when he constantly brings about mental awareness,lg==
and night and day zealously studies,lg==
his biases are extinguished and his mind is full of understanding.lg==
He can gain the path of perfect rest.lg==
A wise man must keep to the prohibitory precepts,lg==
and cultivate wisdom with concentrated mind!lg==
When a bhiksu knows no vexationlg==
and eliminates fruition, all his suffering will be done away with.lg==
He who constantly subdues his thoughts with the precepts,lg==
and guards his mind in right concentration,lg==
who internally trains himself in tranquility and insight,lg==
knows no forgetfulness and is someone who possesses the right knowledge. (DS: and never forgets to cultivate the correct intellect)lg==
Cleanse youself of all stains of sin!lg==
Extinguish conceit and do not have doubts!lg==
Strive all your life after the precepts of law,lg==
and do not forsake noble mindfulness (to this).lg==
Deliverance through morality, concentration and wisdomlg==
must be well comtemplated!lg==
He who has extinguished affliction and does not bring it about,lg==
is stainless. (DS: When somebody has extricated himself from the dust, all the afflictions will not arise)lg==
Through gathering what is pure one attains deliverance,lg==
and so ignorance is completely stopped.lg==
Having passed beyond the realm of Māralg==
one shines like the beams of sun.lg==
Self-conceit and slothfulnesslg==
a bhiksu must shun!lg==
The three kinds of behaviour: morality, concentration, and wisdomlg==
must be sought after and not abandoned.lg==
Not indulging in negligence,lg==
relinquish all notion of object!lg==
Therefore, cast of covering,lg==
and not bring about such obstruction!lg==
When the bhiksu guards the prohibitory preceptslg==
and always looks at those who train themselves in them,lg==
he goes stright on the path of nirvanalg==
and thus speedily obtain purification.lg==
The scent of flowers, does not go against wind,lg==
namely the scent of the hibiscus and of sandallg==
but the scent of merit is fragnant against the wind.lg==
The scent of the meritorious man is everywhere perceived.lg==
The blue lotus, jasmine,lg==
tagara, and sandal!lg==
The scent of such flowerslg==
is not to be compared to the scent of morality!lg==
When someone can keep the precepts,lg==
is pure and not negligent,lg==
he obtains deliverance through his right knowledge.lg==
This is called the place of happiness.lg==
This path is unsurpassed.lg==
The merits of the noble who eliminates Māra through meditationlg==
are difficult to measure.lg==
They can penetrate the eightfold rihgt path.lg==
Beware of evil bodily conduct!lg==
Watch properly over your bodily conduct!lg==
He who guards himself against bodily evillg==
constantly cultivates good bodily conduct.lg==
Beware of evil verbal conduct!lg==
Watch properly over your verbal conduct!lg==
He who guards himself agaist verbal evillg==
constantly cultivates good verbal conduct.lg==
Beware of evil mental conduct!lg==
Watch properly over your mental conduct!lg==
He who guards himself agaist mental evillg==
constantly cultivates good mental conduct.lg==
The body must reject evil conduct,lg==
and one must reject evil verbal conduct!lg==
The mind too must reject evil conduct,lg==
and all faults.lg==
The body must cultivate good conduct!lg==
Cultivate your speech as well!lg==
Those who also cultivate what is mentally goodlg==
extinguish all biases, having no desires.lg==
The body must cultivate good conduct!lg==
When one cultivates speech and mind just so,lg==
one forever obtains in the present world and in the next worldlg==
birth in a wholesome place.lg==
He who is kind and observes (the rule) not to kill,lg==
who can always control his body well,lg==
obtains the state without end.lg==
Where he goes, he will by no means be grieved.lg==
He who does not commit murder and is kind,lg==
who is always well on his guard against words that go too far,lg==
obtains the state without end.lg==
Where he goes, he will by no means be grieved.lg==
The past evil actions of the bodylg==
one must regret!lg==
If the present body is not negligent,lg==
knowledge arises and sins are destroyed.lg==
The past evil actions of speechlg==
one must regret!lg==
If one does not speak falsely now,lg==
knowledge arises and sins are destroyed.lg==
The past evil actions in the mindlg==
one must regret!lg==
If the mind is constantly pure now,lg==
knowledge arises and sins are destroyed.lg==
Be brave watching over your body,lg==
and be just as brave watching over your speech!lg==
Be brave watching over your mind!lg==
Be thus towards all fetters!lg==
This state is called immortality.lg==
Where such a one goes he will not be grieved.lg==
Watching over your body is good,lg==
and watching over your speech is just as good!lg==
Watching over your mind is good!lg==
Being watchful in every respect is thus too.lg==
When a bhiksu is watchful in every respect,lg==
He can extinguish the last of all suffering.lg==
This path, keeping pure the three ways of action: cautiousness in speech, purity of mind,lg==
and never doing evil with the body,lg==
is expounded by the great seer.lg==
